title: Learnings from the Gurukulam
body:
This is the first time Iâ€™ve written something with the intent of putting it online for others to see. Despite maintaining a fairly regular journaling practice, I never seriously considered posting my thoughts online until recently. This is mostly for people interested in Carnatic music, but also for friends curious about what I am doing in India.

If you have questions while reading this, just email me and I can update to clarify. I acknowledge that it may be difficult for people not super involved with Carnatic terminology to read this quickly. Iâ€™ve tried to provide links here and there. Also, you can always use google if there is a term you are unfamiliar with!

# Setting the Scene

### Carnatic Saxophone

Saxophone is a new entrant to the Carnatic music scene. It was the legendary Vidwan [Kadri Gopalnath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kadri_Gopalnath) (1949 - 2019) who brought it to the mainstage, making it the third successful western instrument to integrate into Carnatic music. The violin and electric mandolin were the first two, popularized by Baluswamy Dikshitar (1786 - 1859) and [U. Srinivas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U._Srinivas) (1969 - 2014) respectively. I didnâ€™t find a clean link for Baluswamy Dikshitar, so hereâ€™s a detailed [Dikshitar family tree](https://sreenivasaraos.com/tag/baluswamy-dikshitar/) instead. Kadri Sir gave his first full-fledged [katcheri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katcheri) (concert) in 1978, but only after studying with Sangitha Kalanidhi T. V. Gopalakrishnan, did he ascend Carnatic musicâ€™s greatest heights.

### My History with Carnatic Music

Iâ€™ve been learning Classical South Indian music for a while now. I began formal vocal lessons at the age of nine with Smt. Indhu Nagarajan in LA. I picked up the alto saxophone through middle school band and taught myself the basics of Carnatic music before coming under the tutelage of violin Vidwan Delhi P. Sunderrajan. I continued learning from him over Skype until April 2020. I must admit that while I enjoyed learning Carnatic music, it was never to the extent that I would regularly sit myself down to practice. It doesnâ€™t take a genius to conclude that skill-wise, I plateaued early on.

This next part is going to sound like a joke, but bear with me. On December 9, 2020 I woke up with a newfound conviction that I was going to restart formal lessons, practice every single day, and become a proficient Carnatic saxophonist. Unlike many â€œmotivatedâ€ spells lasting a few days or weeks, this felt different. It was internal. I still canâ€™t describe what switch flipped internally, but something definitely changed.

Given Kadri Sirâ€™s untimely passing in 2019, learning from the source of Carnatic saxophone was no longer a possibility. That said, I was set on learning within Kadriâ€™s *bani* (school of music). On December 9, 2020, I took to the interwebs to find disciples of his who would be willing to teach me. I found three main ones: Eluru Rambha Janardhan (E. R. Janardhan or ERJ), Prasant Radhakrishnan, and Sumanth Swaminathan. Figuring my odds of getting a response were highest if I messaged all three, I went ahead and did so. E. R. Janardhan was the only one to respond (and that too within hours of my initial message) and so on December 10, 2020 I embarked on a journey to get better at Carnatic saxophone.

### A Lineage of Restarts

In my very first class (over Skype) Janardhan Sir assessed my abilities and concluded that my foundations were shaky and my technique was not great. Initially I was annoyed. Ten minutes into my first class and he wanted me to throw out everything I had learned over the past seven years. It wasnâ€™t until a few days ago that I realized I was only the next in a long line of restarts. Janardhan Sir told me that when Kadri Sir began learning from TV Gopalakrishnan, he too had to restart at the Sarali Varisai (very first lesson of Carnatic music).

Janardhan Sirâ€™s road to restarting at the Sarali Varisai was a little more windy. Inspired by the meteoric rise of the prodigious Mandolin U. Srinivas, ERJâ€™s father sent him from his native town Eluru to Chennai at a young age to learn mandolin from Subbaraju (disciple of Chembai Vaidyanatha Bhagavathar). Years later after attending some of Kadri Gopalnathâ€™s concerts, E.R. Janardhan decided to pick up the saxophone. To get familiar with the style of music, he attended as many of Kadri Sirâ€™s concerts as possible and began to teach himself the basics. Within a few years he started touring around India as a up and coming saxophonist and even recorded albums. Soon he caught the eye of the maestro himself and came under the tutelage of Kadri Sir. Being self taught, he had placed shadjam, the note â€œSaâ€, as â€œCâ€ on the saxophone (â€œEbâ€ concert pitch). With 20 years of experience and intense experimentation backing his techniques, Kadri had placed shadjam (â€œSaâ€), as â€œGâ€ on the saxophone (â€œBbâ€ concert pitch). He had concluded it was optimal in terms of both ease of playing as well as the instruments musical range. The masterâ€™s reasoning triumphed and despite being a touring professional saxophonist, Janardhan Sir began again at the Sarali Varasi with â€œSaâ€ at the â€œBbâ€ concert pitch.

Why is this relevant? It really isnâ€™t, but itâ€™s an interesting enough side story that not only I, but my guru (teacher), and paramaguru (teacherâ€™s teacher) restarted with the Sarali Varisai, the basics. As a side note, between 2013 and 2014 I played with fingerings that I had taught myself and had set shadjam (â€œSaâ€), as â€œEâ€ on the saxophone. Itâ€™s straight up random why I set it at that so your guess is as good as mine. Funnily enough, it is only after I found a video of ERJ teaching the basics on YouTube did I switch my fingers from â€œEâ€ on the saxophone to â€œGâ€. This made things significantly easier, but it wasnâ€™t until 2020 that my technique went through a revival from â€œoh what on Earth is he doingâ€ to â€œwow that doesnâ€™t sound horribleâ€. Here I am roughly quoting my sister and mother who both pointed this out sometime in the middle of 2021 (I had been playing for around four months at that point).

# Gurukulam

### Leading up to Summer 2022

Fast forward to this past spring. I had been learning for 16 months at this point and had a solid foundation in Carnatic saxophone music, decent technical abilities, and a good intuition for Carnatic music (or so I thought). Much to the chagrin of each and every one of my roommates, I had played nearly every single day over the past 16 months. I say *nearly* because after about 200 days of daily practice, I needed to take a day off to travel. Since the habit had become so much a part of my daily life at that point, I figured that it would be ok to miss a day here or there. This combined with people (family and friends) begging me to not bring my saxophone on vacations.

By this point I had learned ***a lot***. In eight months I had learned more than I did in the seven years preceding it. I have to point out here that this is 85% due to me, the student, and 15% due to the teacher. Both Sunderrajan Sir and Janardhan Sir were fantastic teachers, but the incremental improvements across daily practice compounded in way I couldnâ€™t have imagined. I had been playing roughly an hour a day, which doesnâ€™t sound crazy until I tell you that I probably played 20 minutes a week in the years prior. You always see the graphs (be it from Tim Urban or someone else) showing that 1% better everyday is 37x better in a year, but you donâ€™t realize its power until you literally live it. And so I was living it. I could hear myself getting significantly better (though most roommates will tell you otherwise) as each month went on.

With around 3.5 weeks to kill between my college graduation and my start day (work), I figured I might as well ask Janardhan Sir if I could go live with him and his family and take in person classes. He responded affirmatively and I went ahead and booked my ticket.

### Eluru, Andhra Pradesh

Fast forward a few months and here I am, writing this post from his house in Eluru, Andhra Pradesh. Itâ€™s my first time in Andhra and Iâ€™ve used emotive hand gestures more often than spoken word to communicate with people here. Though itâ€™s still South India, Telugu is the native language and is indecipherable to me, a Tamil and English speaker. Lucky for me conversing at home is made easy by the fact that both Janardhan Sir and his wife Asha akka speak Tamil and English (in addition to others). The same canâ€™t be said for their adorable 2.5 year old, Jitya, who speaks a mix of general baby babble and Telugu.

### What a Day Looks Like

The average day here is fairly intense and involves several hours of play. The day typically starts around 4:45 am and have 1-on-1 class with Janardhan Sir between 5 - 7 am. After this, he usually hops on Skype to take remote classes with students around the world, while I continue to practice for another hour or so. I break to go eat tiffin, usually idli or dosa. After this I lounge for a little bit, watch an episode of Netflix, or take a nap. Then itâ€™s back to practice. After another hour or two of practice, I have class with Sir ( <= 90 min). Then break. Practice. Break. Night class. Sleep. All added together, Iâ€™ve been looking at about \~6 - 10 hours of saxophone a day, broken down into 4 - 5 hours of class and individual practice making up the rest. And yes. Going from 1-2 hours a day to 6 - 10 will make your mouth hurt. My lips bled. What doesnâ€™t kill you makes you stronger.

### Takeaways (So Far)

Naively, I thought I was pretty good at saxophone. The reality of the situation is that Iâ€™m just getting started. Sometimes the skill gap between guru (master) and shishya (student) is obfuscated by the virtual medium through which most classes these days are held. For example, you hear your teacher play something and you repeat back to them. You think to yourself â€œhey yeah this is pretty straightforward. I got it first try.â€ But in doing so you miss a key point. It isnâ€™t to get it right on the first try, it is to never get it wrong, period.

### ER Janardhan is Absurdly Good at Saxophone

This probably sounds like it should have been obvious given that heâ€™s a high quality professional saxophone artist. Every time I sit down with him to play, I am absolutely blown away by the level at which he plays. Despite not practicing regularly since Covid happened (large reduction in the number of concerts taking place), his playing is smooth like butter. Regardless of the ragam or krithis, the muscle memory kicks in immediately, producing music at a moments notice. Contrasted with my self-assessed â€œnote playingâ€, everything he produces is magical. Each swara (note) is intentional and seldom are there errors.

The key difference between him and every other current saxophone artist is the degree to which he is able to smoothly mimic vocal music on the saxophone. Instead of treating the saxophones keys as binaries (either 0 or 1) which take one of two states (open or closed), he plays with gradients. Depending on the particular ragam, he oscillates the various keys in gradient-like fashion to precisely mimic the pitch modulations a vocalist would make by singing. Janardhan Sirâ€™s approach has taken Carnatic music on the saxophone to a whole new level. In my opinion, it is a style of playing that surpasses the *bani* stylings of his guru, Kadri Gopalnath. Despite attaining a god-like status on saxophone, Kadri Sir was limited in his ability to carry out slide gamakams in â€œweightierâ€ ragas like Nasikabhushani, Bhairavi, Thodi, and others. Janardhan Sir often noted that â€œit sounded like a harmoniumâ€ (discrete notes, instead of true gamakas), something he often says about my playing.

### Things Iâ€™ve Learned

I learned many things across the past two weeks.

In terms of music, we covered the following pieces: second speeds of varnams (Mohanam, Abhogi, Navaragamalika, Thodi, Bhairavi), Kamalapthakula (in Brindavana Saaranga), Gurulekha Etuvanti (Gowri Manohari), Magudi (a composition of Kadri Sir), Raghuvamsa (Kadanakuthuhalam), Sudhamayee (Amruthavarshini), and Maha Ganapathim (Nattai, in progress).

On the saxophone specific side, Iâ€™ve been working on getting my single tonguing speed to 130 bpm, double tonguing, and playing cleaner gamakams and spurithams in various ragams. Initially I struggled to tongue clearly at 100 bpm, but I can now comfortably do so at 110 bpm now. Not a terrible increase for a couple days work. Itâ€™s definitely the first time Iâ€™ve sat down for extended periods of time with nothing but the mouthpiece and the neck in order to practice tonguing itself (ex. today I practiced single and double tonguing exercises for two hours straight).

I accidentally learned [circular breathing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_breathing), which shocked Janardhan Sir since it wasnâ€™t something he had taught me. In fact, when it â€œclickedâ€ I wasnâ€™t even attempting to learn it. I was watching Breaking Bad, while practicing tonguing and took a breather only to move my mouth in the precise way to enable continuous breathing. Janardhan Sir chalked it up to the grace of the guru, pointing to the picture of Kadri hanging next to the pictures of his parents and Gods in the prayer room (where we play).

## General Commentary

### Listening to Music

The more you learn, the more you realize you donâ€™t know. The more I learn, the more I realize I donâ€™t know. I would put on a clip by GN Balasubramaniam, KV Narayanaswamy, MD Ramanathan (my favorite), Chembai, TR Mahalingam, or T Brinda, (this list is infinite so Iâ€™ll cut it off here so as to not bore you with more names than you can count) listen to it, and go â€œwow that was fantastic.â€ Brindaâ€™s panchamam in Meru Samana is the clearest note Iâ€™ve heard in my life. GNBâ€™s brigas are unparalleled. MDRâ€™s absolute oneness with laya and bhakti. Here too I can keep going.

The point remains that I chalked it up to greatness and not practice. Sure innate talent and aptitude has a lot to do with the aforementioned generation defining masters, but the strong (extremely strong) likelihood is that it was accompanied by decades of rigorous practice. I had never â€œreallyâ€ actively listened to recordings of the old masters. So Janardhan Sir had me do that. I sat down and actively listened to recordings of KV Narayanaswamy. In an hour of this, I learned more about the essence of Shankarabharanam than I had done in several hours of attempting to play alapanai (rhythm-free soloing). This isnâ€™t to say that alapanai practice and fluency over the notes isnâ€™t needed. Itâ€™s just that it will be harder to reinvent interesting sounding phrases in Shankarabharanam than it is to draw upon the collective wisdom of masters whoâ€™ve dedicated their entire lives to the craft.

### Lessons - Main Takeaways

**Love.** If you arenâ€™t in love with what you are doing, itâ€™s going to be a long journey ahead. My relationship with music pre-2020 December and post-2020 December is completely different. My desires to learn Carnatic Sangeetham have only grown in the time. I attribute this largely to the fact that I genuinely love what I am doing. Iâ€™ve enjoyed playing Carnatic saxophone so much that the only things keeping me from doing this 10+ hours a day for the next few decades is the belief that I am capable of doing more good for the world as a builder of technology and my future roommates.

**Obsession.** You need to be absolutely obsessed with what you are doing. Janardhan Sir often says â€œyou must practice like a rakshasa (demon)â€. To briefly explain this, in Hindu scriptures, demons show the utmost devotion to penance, discipline, and Gods. Iâ€™m still trying to figure out if he was joking about me needing to play each sangathi (song line or variation of a song line) in a krithi upwards of 500 times. Heâ€™s probably not exaggerating.

**Beauty.** Approaching music with the goal of finding beauty makes it more fun. One of my favorite Sanskrit terms is *Nada Brahma*, roughly "Sound is God.â€ I take it as an observance of the spiritual side of the oscillations and vibrations in music, the one true universal language.

**Itâ€™s a long road ahead.** I came to India thinking Iâ€™d leave being able to play advanced topics raga alapanai, kalapanaswarams, and neraval, but leave realizing that Iâ€™ve only begun this journey. There is on the order of thousands of hours of practice, active listening, and deep study of Carnatic music before Iâ€™m able to create music. The distinction here is between playing notes and making music. Iâ€™m closer to the former than the latter. There are times where I really â€œfeelâ€ what it is that I am playing, but there is a long journey before Iâ€™m in a place where I constantly â€œfeelâ€ \~it\~. Creating music is beautiful. Playing notes is boring.

**The details matter.** **Do the hard things.** In my years before meeting Janardhan Sir I developed I lot of bad habits. Unwanted gamakams. Bad finger technique. Bad embouchure. Here too the list is long. Itâ€™s difficult to undo these habits, but I have reversed a lot over the past 18 months. Now itâ€™s ensuring that the changes are permanent. On the other hand, there is a clear duty to properly reproduce the music youâ€™ve been taught. â€œCreative freedomsâ€ as a concept, doesnâ€™t exist until you are at a sufficiently advanced level. Sometimes I ask Sir to simplify difficult gamakams in Magudi, Raghuvamsa Sudha, or the notoriously difficult Bhairavi Varnam, Viriboni. His response is always â€œno.â€ The point of doing difficult things is partially that they are difficult. In properly doing it, you exercise discipline and diligence. An easier gamakam takes more away from the krithi than it provides. The substitution is a short-term gain, but a long-term loss. You can now play the krithi, but havenâ€™t done the hard work. Now what will you do when the next item you learn in the same ragam requires that particular oscillation? I asked to simplify a few gamakams in the Viriboni (Bhairavi). He said no. I said ok. I did the hard work and learned the gamakams. A little while later I learned Shyama Sastryâ€™s famed composition â€œAmba Kamakshiâ€ (Bhairavi). It was significantly easier given the carry over of gamakams.

**Trust.** You need to wholly and completely trust your teacher. When finding teachers, this is often a factor that gets overlooked. When Janardhan Sir teaches me something, I do not doubt it. This is not to say that you shouldnâ€™t ask questions. Sometimes I have questions about minor details like bits of sangathis or layam (rhythm), and these are resolved quickly. You need to accept the fact that they know a lot more than you think and are drawing from decades of knowledge. In this regard, I donâ€™t really question which song he decides to teach me next or what gamakams he has me learn in particular ragams. To see the picture from the puzzle pieces you need to have a lot of assembled puzzle pieces. The teacher often has this perspective, while the student is busy trying to acquire individual puzzle pieces. Trust that your teacher can take you where you want to go.

# Conclusion

What? A conclusion already? Yes. It had to happen. I know the entire post is rather jumbled and convoluted, but I put off hitting â€œpublishâ€ for a week so I could â€œmake it better.â€ This led to intense procrastination and I figured I would just add a few sections, put it up, and then publish more posts to cover gaping holes from this one.

I wrote this to not only update my friends on what Iâ€™ve been up to, but also to write more about the process of learning music, getting better at things, and preserving culture & traditions. When we see music videos on places like YouTube, the masters are always absurdly good. Yet, there is nothing preserved from their journey. There is no video of MD Ramanathan singing before he went and learned from Tiger Varadachariar. There is no video of Ed Sheeran singing mediocrely before his career took off. I think there is a lot to be learned from this uncovered section -- between beginner and expert.

Iâ€™m still thinking about this, but specific to Carnatic music, there isnâ€™t a great way of preserving the centuries of knowledge accumulated within individuals. Janardhan Sir has a lot of anecdotes about learning from Kadri that heâ€™s mentioned to me, but if never written down, will surely fade. For example, prior to last week, Iâ€™d never heard of Kadri restarting from Sarali Varisai when he met TVG or ER Janardhan restarting when he came under Kadriâ€™s tutelage. Small details like this can and should be preserved by the current artistes and students.

But you say â€œSuraj, surely youâ€™ve heard of lec-dems!â€ The concept of Lec-dem serves to meet these needs, but so only partially. Thereâ€™s only so much you can cover in an hour or two. Technology can help us preserve things and I feel that the Carnatic scene has failed to properly embrace that. If more musicians blogged about their learnings, teachers, and various related components, it would hands down contribute to the richness of our shared culture. Iâ€™m still figuring that one out, but in the meantime I figured Iâ€™d start a blog. â€œBe the change you want to see.â€

If absolutely anything Iâ€™ve written about is interesting, feel free to email me at surajsrivats0112@gmail.com. Iâ€™m happy to go into deeper detail about anything here in a future post and finding out what to focus on can easily be determined by what you personally find interesting. I anticipate Iâ€™ll be writing a lot more about music, Carnatic music, saxophone, general learnings, tech, and a whole host of other things.

title: Volition et le spectre de la Data Availability Ã©mergentes
body:
*[Initialement publiÃ©](https://medium.com/starkware/volition-and-the-emerging-data-availability-spectrum-87e8bfa09bb)Â en anglais par StarkWare le 14 juin, 2020*

*La data availability nâ€™est pas une dichotomie on-chain / off-chain*

### TL;DR

La data availability est un domaine riche, et non une dichotomie on-chain / off-chain. Les dÃ©ploiements StarkEx couvriront tout ce domaine. Les instances StarkEx peuvent actuellement Ãªtre dÃ©ployÃ©es en mode Rollup (donnÃ©es on-chain) ou en mode Validium (donnÃ©es off-chain). Le tout premier dÃ©ploiement de StarkEx est un Validium.

Nous dÃ©crivons un nouveau design : Volition, une solution de donnÃ©es hybride on-chain/off-chain, qui permet aux utilisateurs de choisir de maniÃ¨re dynamique lâ€™endroit oÃ¹ ils souhaitent stocker leurs donnÃ©es. StarkEx supportera Volition bientÃ´t.

### Contexte

Nous avons rÃ©cemment lancÃ© [le premier dÃ©ploiement StarkEx sur Ethereum Mainnet](https://mirror.xyz/0x568B12eBBE85521D2cd8a2C9B7a8EF3f48aa2d66/WGHmqSngZuCC3TlOENDA5mjltEPRJUgQKh5mmyoURVQ). Ce dÃ©ploiement alimente le DEX DeversiFi . La solution Data Availability (DA) sÃ©lectionnÃ©e par DeversiFi dispose de donnÃ©es stockÃ©es off-chain par un comitÃ© DA ([DAC](https://mirror.xyz/0x568B12eBBE85521D2cd8a2C9B7a8EF3f48aa2d66/gV3iTAbP687d1VVAqGCiFnFPLfB2kzHzndkzfnK1oOQ)). DeversiFi a choisi cette solution pour la V1.0 de son DEX car ses clients â€“ les traders professionnels â€“ ne peuvent pas enregistrer leurs historiques de trading on-chain, car cela exposerait leurs stratÃ©gies aux concurrents. DeversiFi a optÃ© pour une solution qui rÃ©pond Ã  un besoin important de ses clients, tout en minimisant leur confiance dans le DAC. A noter : une autre raison pour laquelle DeversiFi a optÃ© pour une solution de donnÃ©es off-chain est la scalabilitÃ© : elle permet la liquiditÃ©, une propriÃ©tÃ© importante pour un DEX Ã©mergent.

Une discussion sur la nomenclature a suivi notre lancement pour nommer correctement diffÃ©rentes solutions de scaling, en tenant compte de leur approche DA. Nous avons proposÃ© dâ€™amÃ©liorer les dÃ©finitions comme suit.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3mh_mc2pXtg1HrbVAhNJn.png?height=288&width=770)

Selon ces dÃ©finitions, le nouveau DEX DeversiFi fonctionne en mode Validium.

### **Motivation**

Nous croyons que DA est une propriÃ©tÃ© importante dâ€™une solution de scaling. Nous savons que diffÃ©rentes applications, diffÃ©rents utilisateurs, diffÃ©rents opÃ©rateurs ont tous leurs besoins particuliers, qui influencent leurs choix DA. Les entreprises qui dÃ©veloppent des solutions de scaling devront offrir une gamme dâ€™offres pour rÃ©pondre Ã  cette diversitÃ© de besoins des clients/utilisateurs.

Au cours de la derniÃ¨re annÃ©e, nous avons consacrÃ© des efforts considÃ©rables Ã  la recherche de lâ€™espace design DA. Il sâ€™agit dâ€™un espace multidimensionnel riche, et la comprÃ©hension de lâ€™Ã©cosystÃ¨me progressera sÃ»rement Ã  mesure que les blockchains se dÃ©velopperont. Notre espoir est dâ€™expliquer les compromis existants que nous observons et de rechercher des moyens de les rÃ©duire. Plus prÃ©cisÃ©ment, nous nous engageons Ã  poursuivre des modÃ¨les de DA qui Ã©voluent sous-linÃ©airement (cÃ d. qui scale mieux que ZK-Rollups); Ã  mesure que la congestion sur Ethereum augmente, de tels modÃ¨les deviendront de plus en plus importants. Si Ethereum devient lâ€™infrastructure publique omniprÃ©sente que nous nous attendons Ã  ce quâ€™il soit, il est impossible d'Ã©viter cette exigence. Cet article dÃ©crit quelques tentatives diffÃ©rentes pour y remÃ©dier.

### Volition

La proposition de valeur que nous visons est simple : donner aux utilisateurs la libertÃ© de choisir â€“ de leur plein grÃ© â€“ leurs prÃ©fÃ©rences en matiÃ¨re de data availability au niveau de chaque transaction, Ã  tout moment, pour nâ€™importe quel type dâ€™actif et pour nâ€™importe quel montant. Imaginez une trading firm, avec son profil risque/rendement, qui dicte ses prÃ©fÃ©rences pour stocker des fonds en toute sÃ©curitÃ© et bÃ©nÃ©ficier de frais de transaction peu Ã©levÃ©s. Dans une telle entreprise, une journÃ©e de trading commencerait par le transfert de fonds de ses traders sur le compte de donnÃ©es off-chain (OFFD), oÃ¹ ils peuvent trader frÃ©quemment et Ã  moindre coÃ»t tout au long de la journÃ©e. Ã€ la fermeture des bureaux, pour des raisons de sÃ©curitÃ©, tous les fonds seront transfÃ©rÃ©s Ã  un compte de donnÃ©es on-chain (OND).

Conceptuellement, chaque compte StarkEx sera dÃ©fini comme un OFFD ou un OND. Un utilisateur peut contrÃ´ler plusieurs comptes et transfÃ©rer des fonds entre eux, au besoin. StarkEx produit une preuve par lot de transactions. Une preuve qui comprend des transactions impliquant un compte OND doit inclure comme entrÃ©e publique (call data) la â€œbalance post-batchâ€ (solde prÃ©cÃ©dent le lot) de ces comptes.

Il convient donc de mettre Ã  jour le diagramme ci-dessus :

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/c_jArRql2sFcZhcoMkTcO.png?height=288&width=770)

Nous mettons en Å“uvre cette conception et fournirons bientÃ´t des dÃ©tails supplÃ©mentaires sur son dÃ©ploiement.

### **Vie privÃ©e**

Les solutions actuellement disponibles sur le marchÃ© souffrent de problÃ¨mes de protection de la vie privÃ©e. Comme mentionnÃ© ci-dessus, les prÃ©occupations en matiÃ¨re de protection de la vie privÃ©e ont poussÃ© DeversiFi Ã  choisir sa premiÃ¨re version StarkEx. Les systÃ¨mes combinant Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKP) et cryptage permettent de rendre les donnÃ©es privÃ©es. Ceci peut Ãªtre appliquÃ© Ã  OND (Rollup) et OFFD (Validium), pour offrir aux utilisateurs une meilleure confidentialitÃ©.

OND : Nous avons un design pour publier des donnÃ©es chiffrÃ©es on-chain. Cela permettrait aux traders de bÃ©nÃ©ficier de la sÃ©curitÃ© dâ€™un Rollup, sans compromettre leur vie privÃ©e et exposer leurs stratÃ©gies de trading.

OFFD : La protection de la vie privÃ©e permet aux membres du DAC de ne pas abuser de leur rÃ´le : ils pourraient toujours attester de la data availability, mais sans connaÃ®tre les dÃ©tails des transactions ou des soldes. Par consÃ©quent, le nombre de membres du DAC StarkEx pourrait Ãªtre multipliÃ© par dix (par rapport Ã  sa taille actuelle dâ€™une demi-douzaine de membres). Avec un DAC plus grand, le quorum pour les signatures par lots pourrait Ã©galement Ãªtre augmentÃ©. De plus, les responsabilitÃ©s des membres du DAC seraient rÃ©duites Ã  la signature stricte pour chaque lot traitÃ© par StarkEx ; les donnÃ©es pourraient Ãªtre rendues publiques â€“ les membres du DAC ne seraient plus chargÃ©s de garder les donnÃ©es confidentielles.

En conclusion, lâ€™ajout de la confidentialitÃ© Ã  StarkEx, quelle que soit la configuration choisie, peut en faire une offre meilleure et plus sÃ©curisÃ©e.

### Minimally Viable Rollback (MVR)

Lors de lâ€™examen des solutions OFFD, une prÃ©occupation est une attaque de donnÃ©es indisponibles : si lâ€™opÃ©rateur et le DAC sont compromis, on peut passer le systÃ¨me Ã  un nouvel Ã©tat sans publier les donnÃ©es nÃ©cessaires (crÃ©er un Ã©tat indisponible).

MVR rÃ©sout ce problÃ¨me en permettant un rollback dâ€™un Ã©tat non disponible de donnÃ©es vers un Ã©tat diffÃ©rent, pour lequel des donnÃ©es sont disponibles. Il le fait tout en prÃ©servant la solvabilitÃ© dans le nouvel Ã©tat rÃ©troactif (state_new), Ã©vitant ainsi les doubles dÃ©penses. Dans un systÃ¨me MVR, chaque retrait est accompagnÃ© de la soumission, on-chain, des dÃ©tails de toutes les transactions qui alimentent le vault retirÃ© (dans les derniers lots). State_new est basÃ© sur un Ã©tat rÃ©cent (state_recent), dont les donnÃ©es sont disponibles, mais nâ€™en est pas une simple copie. Il sâ€™agit plutÃ´t dâ€™un Ã©tat Â« solvant Â», intÃ©grant tous les flux rÃ©cents entrants et sortants de StarkEx (dans les derniers lots) qui ont abouti Ã  des retraits. Cela permet aux utilisateurs de se retirer du nouvel Ã©tat.

La conception MVR empÃªche lâ€™attaque suivante (Â«double dÃ©penseÂ») : lâ€™attaquant retire des fonds aprÃ¨s state_recent, puis dÃ©place le systÃ¨me vers un Ã©tat non disponible ; une fois que le systÃ¨me revient Ã  state_recent, lâ€™attaquant rÃ©cupÃ¨re les fonds dÃ©jÃ  retirÃ©s.

Avec MVR, tant que lâ€™attaque est dÃ©tectÃ©e dans des lots k, le systÃ¨me peut revenir Ã  state_new, car les preuves soumises dans ces lots contiennent suffisamment dâ€™informations pour construire un Ã©tat solvable.

En terme de scalabilitÃ©, certaines donnÃ©es sont donc envoyÃ©es on-chain, comme dans le cas courant, moins que dans un rollup (dans le pire des cas : autant qu'un rollup). Avec une conception correcte du systÃ¨me utilisant [des retraits rapides](https://mirror.xyz/0x568B12eBBE85521D2cd8a2C9B7a8EF3f48aa2d66/AVQ4CiPXyvGs7XUqHXii7BqvazuX7MRaI1KCiyRb_N8), il nâ€™y aura mÃªme pas dâ€™entrÃ©e publique supplÃ©mentaire par rapport Ã  un Validium.

Pour une description un peu plus dÃ©taillÃ©e, y compris la faÃ§on dont state_new est calculÃ©, [lisez ici.](https://ethresear.ch/t/mvr-minimally-viable-rollback/7538)

### Trustless Off-Chain Data Availability (TODA)

Dans TODA, les utilisateurs peuvent fonctionner en toute confiance, en choisissant de devenir un Power User (PU). Les fonds dâ€™un PU sont toujours sous leur garde : en gÃ©nÃ©ral, un UP fournit une signature par preuve, tout comme les membres du DAC. Par sa signature, un UP confirme quâ€™il a accÃ¨s Ã  son propre OFFD, ce qui lui permet dâ€™activer la trappe dâ€™urgence, mÃªme si les membres du DAC ne respectent pas leur rÃ´le de publication de toutes les donnÃ©es. En lâ€™absence dâ€™une telle signature en temps opportun, les fonds de lâ€™UP sont automatiquement retirÃ©s on-chain dans le smart contract dâ€™application â€“ il sâ€™agit dâ€™un retrait protecteur, qui est au cÅ“ur de lâ€™amÃ©lioration trustlessness TODA.

Un utilisateur qui prÃ©fÃ¨re ne pas Ãªtre un PU peut choisir Ã  la place de faire confiance Ã  une entitÃ© off-chain, bien qu'il ne soit plus limitÃ© Ã  faire confiance Ã  un membre du DAC - il peut choisir de faire confiance Ã  tout PU dÃ©sireux de servir de tour de guet en son nom (et devra autoriser ce PU Ã  le faire). Nous publierons une description complÃ¨te de ce protocole dans quelques temps.

### Conclusion

La DA est un Ã©lÃ©ment essentiel de tout systÃ¨me blockchain scalable. L'Ã©cosystÃ¨me blockchain, et StarkWare en particulier, dÃ©ploie des efforts considÃ©rables pour explorer cet espace de conception. Cet article a dÃ©crit quelques-unes des conceptions les plus intÃ©ressantes que nous avons en tÃªte, notamment Volition, oÃ¹ les utilisateurs sont libres de choisir si leurs donnÃ©es rÃ©sident on-chain/off-chain, chaque fois qu'ils effectuent une transaction.

*\~Tom Brand, Avihu Levy, Uri Kolodny*

title: Learnings from the Gurukulam
body:
This is the first time Iâ€™ve written something with the intent of putting it online for others to see. Despite maintaining a fairly regular journaling practice, I never seriously considered posting my thoughts online until recently. This is mostly for people interested in Carnatic music, but also for friends curious about what I am doing in India.

If you have questions while reading this, just email me and I can update to clarify. I acknowledge that it may be difficult for people not super involved with Carnatic terminology to read this quickly. Iâ€™ve tried to provide links here and there. Also, you can always use google if there is a term you are unfamiliar with!

# Setting the Scene

### Carnatic Saxophone

Saxophone is a new entrant to the Carnatic music scene. It was the legendary Vidwan [Kadri Gopalnath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kadri_Gopalnath) (1949 - 2019) who brought it to the mainstage, making it the third successful western instrument to integrate into Carnatic music. The violin and electric mandolin were the first two, popularized by Baluswamy Dikshitar (1786 - 1859) and [U. Srinivas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U._Srinivas) (1969 - 2014) respectively. I didnâ€™t find a clean link for Baluswamy Dikshitar, so hereâ€™s a detailed [Dikshitar family tree](https://sreenivasaraos.com/tag/baluswamy-dikshitar/) instead. Kadri Sir gave his first full-fledged [katcheri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katcheri) (concert) in 1978, but only after studying with Sangitha Kalanidhi T. V. Gopalakrishnan, did he ascend Carnatic musicâ€™s greatest heights.

### My History with Carnatic Music

Iâ€™ve been learning Classical South Indian music for a while now. I began formal vocal lessons at the age of nine with Smt. Indhu Nagarajan in LA. I picked up the alto saxophone through middle school band and taught myself the basics of Carnatic music before coming under the tutelage of violin Vidwan Delhi P. Sunderrajan. I continued learning from him over Skype until April 2020. I must admit that while I enjoyed learning Carnatic music, it was never to the extent that I would regularly sit myself down to practice. It doesnâ€™t take a genius to conclude that skill-wise, I plateaued early on.

This next part is going to sound like a joke, but bear with me. On December 9, 2020 I woke up with a newfound conviction that I was going to restart formal lessons, practice every single day, and become a proficient Carnatic saxophonist. Unlike many â€œmotivatedâ€ spells lasting a few days or weeks, this felt different. It was internal. I still canâ€™t describe what switch flipped internally, but something definitely changed.

Given Kadri Sirâ€™s untimely passing in 2019, learning from the source of Carnatic saxophone was no longer a possibility. That said, I was set on learning within Kadriâ€™s *bani* (school of music). On December 9, 2020, I took to the interwebs to find disciples of his who would be willing to teach me. I found three main ones: Eluru Rambha Janardhan (E. R. Janardhan or ERJ), Prasant Radhakrishnan, and Sumanth Swaminathan. Figuring my odds of getting a response were highest if I messaged all three, I went ahead and did so. E. R. Janardhan was the only one to respond (and that too within hours of my initial message) and so on December 10, 2020 I embarked on a journey to get better at Carnatic saxophone.

### A Lineage of Restarts

In my very first class (over Skype) Janardhan Sir assessed my abilities and concluded that my foundations were shaky and my technique was not great. Initially I was annoyed. Ten minutes into my first class and he wanted me to throw out everything I had learned over the past seven years. It wasnâ€™t until a few days ago that I realized I was only the next in a long line of restarts. Janardhan Sir told me that when Kadri Sir began learning from TV Gopalakrishnan, he too had to restart at the Sarali Varisai (very first lesson of Carnatic music).

Janardhan Sirâ€™s road to restarting at the Sarali Varisai was a little more windy. Inspired by the meteoric rise of the prodigious Mandolin U. Srinivas, ERJâ€™s father sent him from his native town Eluru to Chennai at a young age to learn mandolin from Subbaraju (disciple of Chembai Vaidyanatha Bhagavathar). Years later after attending some of Kadri Gopalnathâ€™s concerts, E.R. Janardhan decided to pick up the saxophone. To get familiar with the style of music, he attended as many of Kadri Sirâ€™s concerts as possible and began to teach himself the basics. Within a few years he started touring around India as a up and coming saxophonist and even recorded albums. Soon he caught the eye of the maestro himself and came under the tutelage of Kadri Sir. Being self taught, he had placed shadjam, the note â€œSaâ€, as â€œCâ€ on the saxophone (â€œEbâ€ concert pitch). With 20 years of experience and intense experimentation backing his techniques, Kadri had placed shadjam (â€œSaâ€), as â€œGâ€ on the saxophone (â€œBbâ€ concert pitch). He had concluded it was optimal in terms of both ease of playing as well as the instruments musical range. The masterâ€™s reasoning triumphed and despite being a touring professional saxophonist, Janardhan Sir began again at the Sarali Varasi with â€œSaâ€ at the â€œBbâ€ concert pitch.

Why is this relevant? It really isnâ€™t, but itâ€™s an interesting enough side story that not only I, but my guru (teacher), and paramaguru (teacherâ€™s teacher) restarted with the Sarali Varisai, the basics. As a side note, between 2013 and 2014 I played with fingerings that I had taught myself and had set shadjam (â€œSaâ€), as â€œEâ€ on the saxophone. Itâ€™s straight up random why I set it at that so your guess is as good as mine. Funnily enough, it is only after I found a video of ERJ teaching the basics on YouTube did I switch my fingers from â€œEâ€ on the saxophone to â€œGâ€. This made things significantly easier, but it wasnâ€™t until 2020 that my technique went through a revival from â€œoh what on Earth is he doingâ€ to â€œwow that doesnâ€™t sound horribleâ€. Here I am roughly quoting my sister and mother who both pointed this out sometime in the middle of 2021 (I had been playing for around four months at that point).

# Gurukulam

### Leading up to Summer 2022

Fast forward to this past spring. I had been learning for 16 months at this point and had a solid foundation in Carnatic saxophone music, decent technical abilities, and a good intuition for Carnatic music (or so I thought). Much to the chagrin of each and every one of my roommates, I had played nearly every single day over the past 16 months. I say *nearly* because after about 200 days of daily practice, I needed to take a day off to travel. Since the habit had become so much a part of my daily life at that point, I figured that it would be ok to miss a day here or there. This combined with people (family and friends) begging me to not bring my saxophone on vacations.

By this point I had learned ***a lot***. In eight months I had learned more than I did in the seven years preceding it. I have to point out here that this is 85% due to me, the student, and 15% due to the teacher. Both Sunderrajan Sir and Janardhan Sir were fantastic teachers, but the incremental improvements across daily practice compounded in way I couldnâ€™t have imagined. I had been playing roughly an hour a day, which doesnâ€™t sound crazy until I tell you that I probably played 20 minutes a week in the years prior. You always see the graphs (be it from Tim Urban or someone else) showing that 1% better everyday is 37x better in a year, but you donâ€™t realize its power until you literally live it. And so I was living it. I could hear myself getting significantly better (though most roommates will tell you otherwise) as each month went on.

With around 3.5 weeks to kill between my college graduation and my start day (work), I figured I might as well ask Janardhan Sir if I could go live with him and his family and take in person classes. He responded affirmatively and I went ahead and booked my ticket.

### Eluru, Andhra Pradesh

Fast forward a few months and here I am, writing this post from his house in Eluru, Andhra Pradesh. Itâ€™s my first time in Andhra and Iâ€™ve used emotive hand gestures more often than spoken word to communicate with people here. Though itâ€™s still South India, Telugu is the native language and is indecipherable to me, a Tamil and English speaker. Lucky for me conversing at home is made easy by the fact that both Janardhan Sir and his wife Asha akka speak Tamil and English (in addition to others). The same canâ€™t be said for their adorable 2.5 year old, Jitya, who speaks a mix of general baby babble and Telugu.

### What a Day Looks Like

The average day here is fairly intense and involves several hours of play. The day typically starts around 4:45 am and have 1-on-1 class with Janardhan Sir between 5 - 7 am. After this, he usually hops on Skype to take remote classes with students around the world, while I continue to practice for another hour or so. I break to go eat tiffin, usually idli or dosa. After this I lounge for a little bit, watch an episode of Netflix, or take a nap. Then itâ€™s back to practice. After another hour or two of practice, I have class with Sir ( <= 90 min). Then break. Practice. Break. Night class. Sleep. All added together, Iâ€™ve been looking at about \~6 - 10 hours of saxophone a day, broken down into 4 - 5 hours of class and individual practice making up the rest. And yes. Going from 1-2 hours a day to 6 - 10 will make your mouth hurt. My lips bled. What doesnâ€™t kill you makes you stronger.

### Takeaways (So Far)

Naively, I thought I was pretty good at saxophone. The reality of the situation is that Iâ€™m just getting started. Sometimes the skill gap between guru (master) and shishya (student) is obfuscated by the virtual medium through which most classes these days are held. For example, you hear your teacher play something and you repeat back to them. You think to yourself â€œhey yeah this is pretty straightforward. I got it first try.â€ But in doing so you miss a key point. It isnâ€™t to get it right on the first try, it is to never get it wrong, period.

### ER Janardhan is Absurdly Good at Saxophone

This probably sounds like it should have been obvious given that heâ€™s a high quality professional saxophone artist. Every time I sit down with him to play, I am absolutely blown away by the level at which he plays. Despite not practicing regularly since Covid happened (large reduction in the number of concerts taking place), his playing is smooth like butter. Regardless of the ragam or krithis, the muscle memory kicks in immediately, producing music at a moments notice. Contrasted with my self-assessed â€œnote playingâ€, everything he produces is magical. Each swara (note) is intentional and seldom are there errors.

The key difference between him and every other current saxophone artist is the degree to which he is able to smoothly mimic vocal music on the saxophone. Instead of treating the saxophones keys as binaries (either 0 or 1) which take one of two states (open or closed), he plays with gradients. Depending on the particular ragam, he oscillates the various keys in gradient-like fashion to precisely mimic the pitch modulations a vocalist would make by singing. Janardhan Sirâ€™s approach has taken Carnatic music on the saxophone to a whole new level. In my opinion, it is a style of playing that surpasses the *bani* stylings of his guru, Kadri Gopalnath. Despite attaining a god-like status on saxophone, Kadri Sir was limited in his ability to carry out slide gamakams in â€œweightierâ€ ragas like Nasikabhushani, Bhairavi, Thodi, and others. Janardhan Sir often noted that â€œit sounded like a harmoniumâ€ (discrete notes, instead of true gamakas), something he often says about my playing.

### Things Iâ€™ve Learned

I learned many things across the past two weeks.

In terms of music, we covered the following pieces: second speeds of varnams (Mohanam, Abhogi, Navaragamalika, Thodi, Bhairavi), Kamalapthakula (in Brindavana Saaranga), Gurulekha Etuvanti (Gowri Manohari), Magudi (a composition of Kadri Sir), Raghuvamsa (Kadanakuthuhalam), Sudhamayee (Amruthavarshini), and Maha Ganapathim (Nattai, in progress).

On the saxophone specific side, Iâ€™ve been working on getting my single tonguing speed to 130 bpm, double tonguing, and playing cleaner gamakams and spurithams in various ragams. Initially I struggled to tongue clearly at 100 bpm, but I can now comfortably do so at 110 bpm now. Not a terrible increase for a couple days work. Itâ€™s definitely the first time Iâ€™ve sat down for extended periods of time with nothing but the mouthpiece and the neck in order to practice tonguing itself (ex. today I practiced single and double tonguing exercises for two hours straight).

I accidentally learned [circular breathing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_breathing), which shocked Janardhan Sir since it wasnâ€™t something he had taught me. In fact, when it â€œclickedâ€ I wasnâ€™t even attempting to learn it. I was watching Breaking Bad, while practicing tonguing and took a breather only to move my mouth in the precise way to enable continuous breathing. Janardhan Sir chalked it up to the grace of the guru, pointing to the picture of Kadri hanging next to the pictures of his parents and Gods in the prayer room (where we play).

## General Commentary

### Listening to Music

The more you learn, the more you realize you donâ€™t know. The more I learn, the more I realize I donâ€™t know. I would put on a clip by GN Balasubramaniam, KV Narayanaswamy, MD Ramanathan (my favorite), Chembai, TR Mahalingam, or T Brinda, (this list is infinite so Iâ€™ll cut it off here so as to not bore you with more names than you can count) listen to it, and go â€œwow that was fantastic.â€ Brindaâ€™s panchamam in Meru Samana is the clearest note Iâ€™ve heard in my life. GNBâ€™s brigas are unparalleled. MDRâ€™s absolute oneness with laya and bhakti. Here too I can keep going.

The point remains that I chalked it up to greatness and not practice. Sure innate talent and aptitude has a lot to do with the aforementioned generation defining masters, but the strong (extremely strong) likelihood is that it was accompanied by decades of rigorous practice. I had never â€œreallyâ€ actively listened to recordings of the old masters. So Janardhan Sir had me do that. I sat down and actively listened to recordings of KV Narayanaswamy. In an hour of this, I learned more about the essence of Shankarabharanam than I had done in several hours of attempting to play alapanai (rhythm-free soloing). This isnâ€™t to say that alapanai practice and fluency over the notes isnâ€™t needed. Itâ€™s just that it will be harder to reinvent interesting sounding phrases in Shankarabharanam than it is to draw upon the collective wisdom of masters whoâ€™ve dedicated their entire lives to the craft.

### Lessons - Main Takeaways

**Love.** If you arenâ€™t in love with what you are doing, itâ€™s going to be a long journey ahead. My relationship with music pre-2020 December and post-2020 December is completely different. My desires to learn Carnatic Sangeetham have only grown in the time. I attribute this largely to the fact that I genuinely love what I am doing. Iâ€™ve enjoyed playing Carnatic saxophone so much that the only things keeping me from doing this 10+ hours a day for the next few decades is the belief that I am capable of doing more good for the world as a builder of technology and my future roommates.

**Obsession.** You need to be absolutely obsessed with what you are doing. Janardhan Sir often says â€œyou must practice like a rakshasa (demon)â€. To briefly explain this, in Hindu scriptures, demons show the utmost devotion to penance, discipline, and Gods. Iâ€™m still trying to figure out if he was joking about me needing to play each sangathi (song line or variation of a song line) in a krithi upwards of 500 times. Heâ€™s probably not exaggerating.

**Beauty.** Approaching music with the goal of finding beauty makes it more fun. One of my favorite Sanskrit terms is *Nada Brahma*, roughly "Sound is God.â€ I take it as an observance of the spiritual side of the oscillations and vibrations in music, the one true universal language.

**Itâ€™s a long road ahead.** I came to India thinking Iâ€™d leave being able to play advanced topics raga alapanai, kalapanaswarams, and neraval, but leave realizing that Iâ€™ve only begun this journey. There is on the order of thousands of hours of practice, active listening, and deep study of Carnatic music before Iâ€™m able to create music. The distinction here is between playing notes and making music. Iâ€™m closer to the former than the latter. There are times where I really â€œfeelâ€ what it is that I am playing, but there is a long journey before Iâ€™m in a place where I constantly â€œfeelâ€ \~it\~. Creating music is beautiful. Playing notes is boring.

**The details matter.** **Do the hard things.** In my years before meeting Janardhan Sir I developed I lot of bad habits. Unwanted gamakams. Bad finger technique. Bad embouchure. Here too the list is long. Itâ€™s difficult to undo these habits, but I have reversed a lot over the past 18 months. Now itâ€™s ensuring that the changes are permanent. On the other hand, there is a clear duty to properly reproduce the music youâ€™ve been taught. â€œCreative freedomsâ€ as a concept, doesnâ€™t exist until you are at a sufficiently advanced level. Sometimes I ask Sir to simplify difficult gamakams in Magudi, Raghuvamsa Sudha, or the notoriously difficult Bhairavi Varnam, Viriboni. His response is always â€œno.â€ The point of doing difficult things is partially that they are difficult. In properly doing it, you exercise discipline and diligence. An easier gamakam takes more away from the krithi than it provides. The substitution is a short-term gain, but a long-term loss. You can now play the krithi, but havenâ€™t done the hard work. Now what will you do when the next item you learn in the same ragam requires that particular oscillation? I asked to simplify a few gamakams in the Viriboni (Bhairavi). He said no. I said ok. I did the hard work and learned the gamakams. A little while later I learned Shyama Sastryâ€™s famed composition â€œAmba Kamakshiâ€ (Bhairavi). It was significantly easier given the carry over of gamakams.

**Trust.** You need to wholly and completely trust your teacher. When finding teachers, this is often a factor that gets overlooked. When Janardhan Sir teaches me something, I do not doubt it. This is not to say that you shouldnâ€™t ask questions. Sometimes I have questions about minor details like bits of sangathis or layam (rhythm), and these are resolved quickly. You need to accept the fact that they know a lot more than you think and are drawing from decades of knowledge. In this regard, I donâ€™t really question which song he decides to teach me next or what gamakams he has me learn in particular ragams. To see the picture from the puzzle pieces you need to have a lot of assembled puzzle pieces. The teacher often has this perspective, while the student is busy trying to acquire individual puzzle pieces. Trust that your teacher can take you where you want to go.

# Conclusion

What? A conclusion already? Yes. It had to happen. I know the entire post is rather jumbled and convoluted, but I put off hitting â€œpublishâ€ for a week so I could â€œmake it better.â€ This led to intense procrastination and I figured I would just add a few sections, put it up, and then publish more posts to cover gaping holes from this one.

I wrote this to not only update my friends on what Iâ€™ve been up to, but also to write more about the process of learning music, getting better at things, and preserving culture & traditions. When we see music videos on places like YouTube, the masters are always absurdly good. Yet, there is nothing preserved from their journey. There is no video of MD Ramanathan singing before he went and learned from Tiger Varadachariar. There is no video of Ed Sheeran singing mediocrely before his career took off. I think there is a lot to be learned from this uncovered section -- between beginner and expert.

Iâ€™m still thinking about this, but specific to Carnatic music, there isnâ€™t a great way of preserving the centuries of knowledge accumulated within individuals. Janardhan Sir has a lot of anecdotes about learning from Kadri that heâ€™s mentioned to me, but if never written down, will surely fade. For example, prior to last week, Iâ€™d never heard of Kadri restarting from Sarali Varisai when he met TVG or ER Janardhan restarting when he came under Kadriâ€™s tutelage. Small details like this can and should be preserved by the current artistes and students.

But you say â€œSuraj, surely youâ€™ve heard of lec-dems!â€ The concept of Lec-dem serves to meet these needs, but so only partially. Thereâ€™s only so much you can cover in an hour or two. Technology can help us preserve things and I feel that the Carnatic scene has failed to properly embrace that. If more musicians blogged about their learnings, teachers, and various related components, it would hands down contribute to the richness of our shared culture. Iâ€™m still figuring that one out, but in the meantime I figured Iâ€™d start a blog. â€œBe the change you want to see.â€

If absolutely anything Iâ€™ve written about is interesting, feel free to email me at surajsrivats0112@gmail.com. Iâ€™m happy to go into deeper detail about anything here in a future post and finding out what to focus on can easily be determined by what you personally find interesting. I anticipate Iâ€™ll be writing a lot more about music, Carnatic music, saxophone, general learnings, tech, and a whole host of other things.

title: Hello, Mirror!
body: Just looking around!

title: Web3.0
body:
## How I think about 1 and 2

web3 is a somewhat ambiguous term, which makes it difficult to rigorously evaluate what the ambitions for web3 should be, but the general thesis seems to be that web1 was decentralized, web2 centralized everything into platforms, and that web3 will decentralize everything again. web3 should give us the richness of web2, but decentralized.

Itâ€™s probably good to have some clarity on why centralized platforms emerged to begin with, and in my mind the explanation is pretty simple:

1. **People donâ€™t want to run their own servers, and never will.** The premise for web1 was that everyone on the internet would be both a publisher and consumer of content as well as a publisher and consumer of infrastructure. 
  
 Weâ€™d all have our own web server with our own web site, our own mail server for our own email, our own finger server for our own status messages, our own chargen server for our own character generation. However â€“ and I donâ€™t think this can be emphasized enough â€“ *that is not what people want*. People do not want to run their own servers. 
  
 Even nerds do not want to run their own servers at this point. Even organizations building software full time do not want to run their own servers at this point. If thereâ€™s one thing I hope weâ€™ve learned about the world, itâ€™s that people do not want to run their own servers. The companies that emerged offering to do that for you instead were successful, and the companies that iterated on new functionality based on what is possible with those networks were even more successful.
2. **A protocol moves much more slowly than a platform.** After 30+ years, email is still unencrypted; meanwhile WhatsApp went from unencrypted to full e2ee in a year. People are still trying to standardize sharing a video reliably over IRC; meanwhile, Slack lets you create custom reaction emoji based on your face. 
  
 This isnâ€™t a funding issue. If something is truly decentralized, it becomes very difficult to change, and often remains stuck in time. That is a problem for technology, because the rest of the ecosystem is moving very quickly, and if you donâ€™t keep up you will fail. There are entire parallel industries focused on defining and improving methodologies like Agile to try to figure out how to organize enormous groups of people so that they can *move as quickly as possible* because it is so critical. 
  
 When the technology itself is more conducive to stasis than movement, thatâ€™s a problem. A sure recipe for success has been to take a 90â€™s protocol that was stuck in time, centralize it, and iterate quickly.

But web3 intends to be different, so letâ€™s take a look. In order to get a quick feeling for the space and a better understanding for what the future may hold, I decided to build a couple of dApps and create an NFT.

title: Web3.0
body:
## How I think about 1 and 2

web3 is a somewhat ambiguous term, which makes it difficult to rigorously evaluate what the ambitions for web3 should be, but the [general thesis](https://future.a16z.com/why-web3-matters/) seems to be that web1 was decentralized, web2 centralized everything into platforms, and that web3 will decentralize everything again. web3 should give us the richness of web2, but decentralized.

Itâ€™s probably good to have some clarity on why centralized platforms emerged to begin with, and in my mind the explanation is pretty simple:

1. **People donâ€™t want to run their own servers, and never will.** The premise for web1 was that everyone on the internet would be both a publisher and consumer of content as well as a publisher and consumer of infrastructure. 
  
 Weâ€™d all have our own web server with our own web site, our own mail server for our own email, our own finger server for our own status messages, our own chargen server for our own character generation. However â€“ and I donâ€™t think this can be emphasized enough â€“ *that is not what people want*. People do not want to run their own servers. 
  
 Even nerds do not want to run their own servers at this point. Even organizations building software full time do not want to run their own servers at this point. If thereâ€™s one thing I hope weâ€™ve learned about the world, itâ€™s that people do not want to run their own servers. The companies that emerged offering to do that for you instead were successful, and the companies that iterated on new functionality based on what is possible with those networks were even more successful.
2. **A protocol [moves much more slowly than a platform](https://signal.org/blog/the-ecosystem-is-moving/).** After 30+ years, email is still unencrypted; meanwhile WhatsApp went from unencrypted to full e2ee in a year. People are still trying to standardize sharing a video reliably over IRC; meanwhile, Slack lets you create custom reaction emoji based on your face. 
  
 This isnâ€™t a funding issue. If something is truly decentralized, it becomes very difficult to change, and often remains stuck in time. That is a problem for technology, because the rest of the ecosystem is moving very quickly, and if you donâ€™t keep up you will fail. There are entire parallel industries focused on defining and improving methodologies like Agile to try to figure out how to organize enormous groups of people so that they can *move as quickly as possible* because it is so critical. 
  
 When the technology itself is more conducive to stasis than movement, thatâ€™s a problem. A sure recipe for success has been to take a 90â€™s protocol that was stuck in time, centralize it, and iterate quickly.

But web3 intends to be different, so letâ€™s take a look. In order to get a quick feeling for the space and a better understanding for what the future may hold, I decided to build a couple of dApps and create an NFT.
